awd_titl_txt: EAGER: Collaborative Research: Designing Digital Rails to Foster Scientific Curiosity around Museum Collections
awd_abstract_narration:
One of the best ways to engage people in Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (STEM) at a young age is through informal museum experiences. Yet, the research base on understanding how learning and engagement develops through these experiences is still emerging. Technology opens new ways to research these experiences to understand these processes better. In this proposal, researchers from Northwestern University and the Chicago Field Museum will collaborate to develop digital interactive displays to enhance the experience at various exhibits by providing additions varying in complexity from simple menu navigation, to 3D model manipulation, to fully interactive games. These will replace the typical static plaques that go along with an exhibit. In addition to enhancing the experience with the exhibits, these displays allow researchers to collect more data on people's interaction with exhibits, particularly touch screen information regarding how visitors interacted with the 3D models, games and touchscreens. The proposed research will help address questions regarding the role of games in learning, for instance, do these games provide enhanced motivation and learning, or do they limit social interaction and create small silos in the midst of a group experience? It will also answer questions about how creativity is fostered in these environments by observing interactions and combining that with the digital data collected for a fuller picture of the development of engagement and learning.

Researchers from Northwestern University and the Chicago Field Museum will develop digital rails, interactive computer displays mounted on exhibit case railings that function as dynamic labels and provide enhanced experience features such as the integration of 3D modeling and games. They propose to augment the digital rails with near-field communication (NFC) tracking devices (RFID readers) to monitor amount of interaction and to link with user cell phones. They will collect NFC tracking data, computer logs of touch interaction, and interaction with mobile apps and observe visitor behavior around the interactive display cases. This early stage research study will employ design-based research to investigate this new form of interactive technology. Through iterating on observations and linking the observational data with the digitally collected data, the team will develop an understanding of the design principles for digital rails that best foster interactivity, social interaction, creativity, and learning of the material the exhibits focus on.

por.por_cntn:
With the assistance of NSF EAGER award #1550055 researchers from Northwestern University's Learning Sciences and Computer Sciences teams joined staff from the Field Museum's Exhibitions and Audience Insights Departments to complete a multi-year two-phase study of a digital medium for providing visitor experiences in a natural history museum. Referred to as a digital rail, this touch screen interactive was designed to provide all object-oriented information in the Museum's recently-completed ​Cyrus Tang Hall of China​ and to enhance the visitor experience with a widened variety of content types to explore.   

Northwestern's main research focus was role the digital rails could play in increasing curiosity. Put simply: could this new way of presenting information increase a visitor's desire to want to know more? The project involved taking the digital rails in their current state, re-arranging the order of their content in several experimental iterations, and assessing visitor responses to the different versions. The most significant finding of the study was that the interactive and multimedia components of the digital rails could be used to increase the attracting power of an object display. Bringing these components to the very front of the experience (presenting an interactive designed to increase curiosity on the 'home' or 'welcome' screen of the rail) increased the chances that a visitor would stop to read. It did not, however, increase dwell time: visitors did not spend more time at that reading rail than did those who used it in its original form.   

The Field Museum's follow-up study, in contrast, was an evaluation of use of the digital rail medium in the exhibition as a whole. Through tracking and timing observations, as well as card-sort and interviewing activities conducted with visitors, we were able to reach several conclusions.   

From other research in the visitor studies field, we know that the amount of time a visitor spends in an exhibition can vary greatly. Visitors to the ​China Hall​ tend to move quickly, though not at a pace vastly different than in other galleries we have tracked. The average amount of time spent in this 6,000 sq. ft. exhibition was 13 minutes 44 seconds. This equates to a Sweep Rate Index (SRI) of 559. While this is a higher SRI than we would like in the space, we need to better understand how it compares to other anthropological halls in the Field Museum. Furthermore, the SRI does not take into account the percentage of time the visitor spent in the hall as a percentage of their overall visit. This may warrant further investigation. As for the the digital reading rails, while they were not used as frequently as we would have liked, they were positively perceived. Only about one-third of visitors to the exhibition touched a digital rail (a 'user'). Within that group, the average number of rails used in the exhibition was 3.2 (out of 44 total). However, the rails are perceived positively by users and nonusers alike. Furthermore, those who did use a rail in the hall rated their experience higher than nonusers. Overall, visitors rated the rails positively for their specificity and depth of information as well as their usability. Most of the concerns voiced as potential drawbacks of the digital rail medium were not realized. Visitors were not confused by the digital interface, did not feel overwhelmed by the amount of information, and did not view the digital rails as an intrusion on the experience of appreciating the objects on display.   

This comprehensive study of readership of digital interpretation in the ​Cyrus Tang Hall of China has provided data, insights, protocols, and data-collection instruments that can be used to compare reading behaviors for traditional (printed) museum interpretive materials (labels). This will provide further insights into the potential advantages and drawbacks of using similar technologies in future large exhibitions.
